job_title: IT Service Desk Analyst in London, England
pros:
As an openly Gay individual, the workplace is very inclusive and supportive. Lovely people to work with and very supportive. 
Opportunity to do external courses.
Really good pension
Flexible working/Understanding when you need time off. 
Compassionate leave if required
Not required to work after hours, you can switch off after work.
About to move into a modern office.
cons:
Low progression to move from the position if you are valuable in the current position you are in, but does happen very rarely. 
Low pay but it is a charity sector for London, could do with a pay revision in some departments.
A steep environmental learning curve takes around 6 months to learn the basics to be able to do your job with confidence. 
A lot of patience is required with small amount of users that may be more technically challenged than others.
Sometimes feel ignored
Don't find out the resolution of issues, unless you follow up.
High ticket volumes

job_title: Donor Care Assistant in Elephant & Castle, England

cons: Toxic work culture. Supervisors spent their days day online shopping for pillows, abused her staff verbally. They also insulted the donors daily (calling them idiots and cursing them, often commenting on how little they donated). Lazy coworkers who would rather sneaky play on their phones right next to you and make mistakes with their work. All in all, was one of the worse places that I’ve ever worked, especially being a charity.

review_title: Good Management, Good Clients, not so good staff
job_title: Assistant Support Worker in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: The service manager was very supportive, most residents were a pleasure to work with. Good training and management will listen to you.
cons:
Some of the Support Workers were clearly more concerned about their own progression. They talked about each other behind their backs and either failed to support the clients properly or failed to complete the correct paperwork. As I was night shift I was asked to check all the paperwork to ensure it was correct and up to date.

Most of them had some errors but one Support Worker, in particular, was not keeping the records up to date. Of course, I had to report back to the Service Manager and he probably had a talking to about it. I t was well known amongst the other staff that he was not doing his job properly.

I can see that he had an issue with me and at a later point put in an official complaint about me for something he made up. I ended stressed and unable to work.

Management tried to help me but I really could not work in that atmosphere.

pros: The service users we support.
cons:
Don't expect to progress to management level if you are not a 'practicing Christian'. No wonder the business is badly managed when it is more important for those in management roles to attend a church than have the qualifications and experience for the position.
Huge expectations of staff, pressure to meet kpi's even when there are severe staff shortages, making it impossible to meet these targets. Management do not listen, staff undervalued, overworked and wages still being cut.

review_title: Don't look after their loyal staff
pros: Staff are great. Residents and families are lovely. easy to get to. Close to shops. Not one of the lowest paid but certainly not the best.
cons: Important decisions are made by the management who know nothing about the care home. No consultations with the staff that actually work there. If staff make a complaint then management just threaten to close the home down.  Any problems are blamed on the care staff. It can't possibly be managements fault! Short staffed constantly. Basic minimum wage no matter what the qualification. So no insentive to better oneself management always changing the rota so no one knows their shifts from one week to the next.

job_title: Sales Assistant in Preston, North West England, England
pros:
Great Voluntary workforce that should be given more chance to work for the company 
Most days I look forward to going into work.
No two days are the same.
cons:
Bullying and KPI obsessed management means we can't just get on with the job of raising money.
 
Micromanagement from cluster managers leaves staff often confused and weary of making decisions when they are not around. 

Definite Fraudulent activity to meet KPI's

often threatened with "area / regional manager is doing surprise visits"

No time to take dinner breaks when there are no volunteers trained on the till. 

No formal training. 

Expect to work before or after business hours without pay to get admin / cleaning duties done. 

Working additional days to cover staff shortages is not paid, but rather given as days off. 

Booking a day off is like pulling teeth at times. 

Low Pay scale compared to other retail jobs

review_title: I love this place, but the structure will kill it
pros: An amazing organisation doing wonderful work. Great atmosphere and incredible colleagues. Generally speaking, staff are looked after and appreciated. A very special place indeed.
cons: The structures is restricting its ability to really reach out and tells it story, whilst making connections with new supporters. It needs to look to, and listen to, the experts it employs to help guide them to better things.

job_title: Programmer Funding Officer in London, England
pros: You don't have to be a Christian to work there but I reckon it helps. The terms and conditions are generous, the work ethic is strong and there is a positive attitude towards flexible working.
cons: There is a lack of strength and capacity in management at all levels. Salvation Army officers can be moved around the global organisation causing problems of discontinuity and a lack of strategic development.

pros: Good to get job experience, I volunteered here every Wednesday for 2 months and they were very friendly to volunteers. You could do any job if they see they could trust you.
cons:
Soon, I was pretty much doing what full-time workers did but with less pressure. 
Lots of thieves came, so you kinda have to be guarding the shop as well. Other than these two reasons, it was alright.

pros: It was one of the easiest jobs in the world, and very accommodating given the situation I was in. Good Pay and Great Management.
cons: No real cons. I would like to add that my situation was a little different from most employees and was kinda in terms of a favor. Still, was treated no different from other employees which I greatly enjoyed.

pros:
Relatively short working hours for full time employees (35 hours per week). 
Good holiday allowances (start at 25 days)
Company sick pay based on length of service
cons:
Benefits aren't great and salaries are set in stone so no flexibility for example if you become qualified there isn't the opportunity for a pay rise
Statutory only for redundancy, maternity and paternity leave

pros: interesting place to work always something going on.
cons: not a good work life balance, Not flexible at all, was not treated the nicest when i was sick. bullying tactics used by management. not a nice environment to work in. No interest in helping career progression

review_title: Must be part of an exclusive club to succeed
pros:
Lovely surroundings at place I worked at
Several colleagues were genuinely nice people
Fed for free and (in theory) travel expenses paid - though tax/NI for this is taken all at once with no warning
Clive Adams is on the whole very nice, but due to the size of the organisation and others covering each others backs, I don't think he has any real idea of how bad things are. He's in charge in the UK right now. The General, who's head of it worldwide on the other hand, is... less nice. A lot less nice.
cons:
No actual training, tested with unfair and unrealistic situations
Expected to mind read
Extremely stressful
Not enough people to do what needs to be done
Staff blamed for things they have no control over
Yet not allowed to make any actual decisions
And impossible to get hold of managers to get anything approved
Employee reviews inaccurate
No recognition for good work on paper, despite repeated compliments in person from several sources and thank you cards from customers
Managers approve things or make decisions and then conveniently forget what they said when it proves to be problematic. Even when it's on paper and they've signed it
Paperwork linked to things inconvenient to them also mysteriously vanishes on a regular basis
Job did not match description - 'office job' also involved heady lifting, running up and down stairs all day, shifting furniture and equipment etc., so was also physically exhausting
Paperwork did not truthfully reflect events
'Breaks' constantly interrupted and infringed upon by customers and staff alike
Contracted breaks rarely happened beyond lunch in the first place
Constantly overbooked. Workload bordering on ridiculous at times
Pressure to attend 'invited' events of several hours each every few weeks for no additional pay, yet expected to work throughout each
Expected to do additional work in own time
Extra hours constantly. You get them back eventually, but it takes an age because it's always so busy
Similarly virtually impossible to identify opportunities to take holiday
Yet told to get more bookings?
No break from pressure, huge impact on mental health
Most staff didn't know how to do basic things with computers and the like
Blatant favouritism. Even when the person in question had moved on?
Constantly complains they don't have enough officers, then stick them behind a desk in a job anyone could do
Takes officers away from corps that really need them, yet the large ones with literally hundreds of people to help out and multiple officers keep all of theirs?
Assign all the best jobs to their best friends
Constantly compared to predecessor
Managers/officers all friends with each other, making it extremely difficult to be able to voice concerns
Treated very badly if you do
HR extremely unhelpful and purposely obstructive
LOTUS. NOTES.
Bureaucracy on steroids
No real organisation. Chaotic at the best of times
Homophobic, frankly
Hypocritical
Purposely intimidating
Extremely old fashioned
If you play in a big band or sing in a big choir or wear red on your shoulders, the world revolves around you and nobody else matters
Egos the size of Jupiter
Several genuinely nasty officers visited regularly
No accountability, despite huge, expensive accountability campaign being shoved down everyone's throats
No apparent concern for wasting money on vanity projects or to correct issues based on very basic mistakes, despite being a charity
No concern whatsoever for mental (or physical) health of employees
I question the legality of certain practices
Generally very cliquey. Christians do tend to progress more, but this alone isn't enough to succeed. Previously had been an un-uniformed member for many years. Even this was not enough. You have to go to the right corps, wear the right uniform, be an officer, have the right surname and hold multiple unpaid commissions to matter to anybody at all. Needless to say, I am no longer a member.

review_title: The Salvation Army in UK are terrible employers
pros: The only pro that I can think of is that they all pretend to be nice to your face to stick to their Christian values.
cons:
If you are non-white, non-salvationist it is very difficult to work there. You are made to feel different and lower than them if you are not part of their domination and racist undertones exist including the use of disgusting language. including asking a Muslim woman being told to 'just pick the bacon off' her salad (I have many more and worse examples). They are also homophobic.

They act as if they are superior to others as they don't smoke, drink or gamble (not in front of witnesses anyway), instead they just have affairs and pretend as if they didn't happen.

Very inward looking, the most self-centred organisation I have ever worked for. Everyone works for their own gain to improve their status in the army/in corps.  

Management do not care about for their employees (unless you are a salvationist). This organisation fail in many areas around employment law. 

Confidentiality is poor as so many relations (ie husband, wife, sister, brother) work together confidential information easily spreads throughout the head office all the way down to corps level. 

They only care about protecting the brand.

job_title: Family Support Worker in Wisbech, England
pros: There are none to mention
cons: Unaccountable and untrained managers dismissing serious issues brought to their attention. There response, to get rid of the worker making accusations and make it look like its the worker not us! Diabolical - agree with the statement STARVATION ARMY - Much more appropriate title. Very secretive, unaccountable and corrupt from top down.
